Kevin Chu

PhD Candidate in Materials Science | Georgia Tech

Email: kchu41@gatech.edu

About Me

I study fundamental deformation and strengthening mechanisms at the nano and mesoscale to inform the design of novel alloy systems. I leverage and extend existing computational approaches to accomplish these goals. Skills honed during my PhD include:

  • Molecular Dynamics/Monte Carlo methods (LAMMPS)
  • Concurrent Atomistic-Continuum multiscale modeling (CAC)
  • Data analysis and visualization (Scipy, Jupyter, Pandas)
  • Scientific software development (MPI, Fortran90, C++)
  • Scripting and automation (Python, BASH)

Publications

Multiscale Concurrent Atomistic-Continuum (CAC) modeling of multicomponent alloys

Computational Materials Science

https://doi.org/10.1016/j.commatsci.2021.110873

Temperature and composition dependent screw dislocation mobility in austenitic stainless steels from large-scale molecular dynamics

npj Computational Materials

https://doi.org/10.1038/s41524-020-00452-x

Molecular Statics Analyses of Thermodynamics and Kinetics of Hydrogen Cottrell Atmosphere Formation Around Edge Dislocations in Aluminum

JOM

https://doi.org/10.1007/s11837-020-04213-5

Molecular dynamics studies of InGaN growth on nonpolar (11-20) GaN surfaces

Physical Review Materials

https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevMaterials.2.013402

Polymorphic improvement of Stillinger-Weber potential for InGaN

Journal of Applied Physics

https://doi.org/10.1063/1.5001339

Research Positions

Georgia Institute of Technology

Graduate Research Assistant

August 2017 - Present

  • Identified the link between average-atom EAM potentials and concurrent atomistic-continuum (CAC) coarse-grained models, designed and executed validation simulations
  • Contributed to open-source fork of LAMMPS codebase to implemet necessary features for finite-temperature alloy simulations
  • Collaborated with national labs and various university research partners to paint a cohesive picture of deformation in additively-manufactured 316L stainless steels

U.S. Naval Research Laboratory

NREIP Graduate Fellowship

Summer 2021

  • Selected for Naval Research Enterprise Intern Program (NREIP) at the US Naval Research Lab.
  • Designed large-scale Monte-Carlo (MC) annealing algorithms to develop short-range solute ordering in complex alloy systems.
  • Created a Python-based tool to process both atom-probe tomography datasets and MC-computed microstructures to directly quantify cluster size and distributions.

Sandia National Laboratories

R&D Graduate Intern

Summer 2019

Executed molecular dynamics modeling and data analysis activities to support the following projects:

  • Designed rastering algorithm for computing interstitial and substitutional solute site binding energies
  • large scale dislocation mobility analysis in 3XX stainless steels
  • Theorized and implemented a continuum-scale diffusion model and fully pipelined execution and analysis of multi-parameter space molecular dynamics simulations.

Sandia National Laboratories

R&D Undergraduate Intern

Summer 2017

  • Designed and executed molecular dynamics simulations of epitaxially grown crystalline materials using LAMMPS and high performance computing clusters.
  • Discovered correlation between surface pitting defects and interface dislocation nucleation.

Education

Harvard University

BSc Computer Science

2010 - 2013

Established in 1636, Harvard is the oldest higher education institution in the United States, and is widely regarded in terms of its influence, reputation, and academic pedigree as a leading university in not just the US but also the world.

During my time at Harvard I learnt most of my key skills that have I have taken through my career such as teamwork and working to tight deadlines. I thouroughly enjoyed my time as university and learnt a lot about a healthy work life balance.

I spent a lot of my free time as a committee member of the Harvard Mountaineering Club taking on roles such as Trip Secretary and Vice-President.
